abstract: Try a few short problems from The Math League, an extracurricular activity used in China to balance the tedium of studying for the Gaokao, China’s college entrance exam.
snippet: Try a few short problems from The Math League, an extracurricular activity used in China to balance the tedium of studying for the Gaokao, China’s college entrance exam.
lead_paragraph: The notorious Gaokao, (高考, or “High Test”) is China’s SAT on steroids, with a score on the nine-hour test being the sole criterion for admission to Chinese universities. Preparing for the test is a years-long obsession for both students and parents. (In case you missed it: Brook Larmer’s Inside a Chinese Test-Prep Factory.) And for many, the unfortunate consequence is that the lengthy preparation destroys, rather than enhances, academic ability. Student enthusiasm and curiosity are crushed.

headline.main: Breaking the Grip of the Gaokao, China’s SAT

abstract: Although overall bad debt levels remain relatively low, continued deterioration threatens to reverse years of profit growth.
snippet: Although overall bad debt levels remain relatively low, continued deterioration threatens to reverse years of profit growth.
lead_paragraph: China’s economic slowdown is exposing the debt debris in its banking sector. Shaky credits on the balance sheets of the country’s four biggest lenders jumped by 28 percent to 592 billion renminbi ($92.8 billion) in the first half of the year. Further deterioration would send earnings growth into reverse.

headline.main: Slowing Growth Exposes Chinese Banks’ Debt Debris

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China
